comment.author: 71217563@N07
comment._content:
Major George Ivan Carmichael, MC, DFC, RA
Born on 24 Aug 88
2nd Lieut, RA on 18 Dec 08
Lieut., RA on 18 Dec 11
Attached to the RFC on 11 Mar 13
Temp. Capt on 1 May 14
Served in France from 1914 to 31 Mar 1918 with RFC
Captain, RA on 18 Dec 14
DSO (LG 27 Mar 15)
Served as a Temp Major from Mar 1915-Feb 1917
Temp. Lt-Col. from Feb 1917 to Mar 1918
From 1 Apr 18 he was employed under the Air Ministry
Major, RA, 20 May 18
AFC, 1919

comment.author: 71217563@N07
comment._content:
He was born 22 August 1888.Son of Lieutenant Colonel J. Carmichael . Attended RMA Woolwich. RA 1908. & RFC 1912. France & Flanders Mention in Despatches & DSO 1915. Lieutenant Colonel & AFC  1919. Group Captain 1929 Retired 1933. He was the first to  command Northolt, on its opening 3rd March 1915, in the rank of Major RFC of No 4 Reserve Aeroplane Squadron

D.S.O. awarded for destroying the rails at Menin Raileway Station by dropping a bomb.

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Major George Ivan Carmichael, MC, DFC, RA. Born August 1888 Kingstown, Ireland, the son of Lieutenant-Colonel J Carmichael. He attended RMA Woolwich, 
2nd Lieut, RA on 18 Dec 08
Promoted to Lieut., RA on 18 Dec 11
Attached to the RFC on 11 Mar 13
Temp. Capt on 1 May 14
Served in France from 1914 to 31 Mar 1918 with Royal Flying Corps
Promoted to Captain, RA on 18 Dec 14
Awarded DSO (London Gazette 27 Mar 15)
Married Kathleen Mary Foxon Smelt at St John’s Parish Church, Hampstead on 14th September 1915. His occupation is given as Major in Royal Flying Corps. His address is given as “The Areodrome, Norwich]
Served as a Temp Major from Mar 1915-Feb 1917
Temp. Lt-Col. from Feb 1917 to Mar 1918
From 1 Apr 1918 he was employed under the Air Ministry
Major, RA, 20 May 18
Awarded AFC, 1919
Died in the second quarter of 1976, New Forest, Hampshire.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/liits/6440931643/in/photostream]
Photo from the Royal Aero Club

comment.author: 77235581@N00
comment._content:
George Ivan Carmichael's DSO was mentioned in the London Gazette as follows:

Lieutenant (temporary Captain) George Ivan Carmichael, Royal Artillery and Royal Flying Corps.

For conspicuous gallantry, daring, and ability throughout the Campaign.

On the 11th instant [March 1915] he destroyed the rails at Menin railway station by dropping a bomb, weighing 100 lbs, thereon from a height of only 120 feet.

On the return journey his engine was damaged by a bullet which necessitated his flying at a height of less than 200 feet.

Captain Carmichael has also rendered service in observing Artillery fire.

(London Gazette, 27 March 1915, page 3079)
